Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Situation2: They have been scheduled to chant a portion during the service.
Story:
I stared at the calendar on the fridge, my eyes darting between the circled Saturday and the sticky note with “Buy Nintendo for Max” scrawled in my partner’s handwriting. Max had been counting down the days, his excitement bubbling over every time he mentioned the game he’d play first. I wanted to keep my promise, to show him that I could be counted on, that I was really part of this family. But the cost gnawed at me—money was tight, and I’d already stretched the budget thin.

At the same time, my phone buzzed with a reminder from the synagogue. I was scheduled to chant Torah this Shabbat, something I’d committed to months ago. It wasn’t just about showing up; it was about honoring my faith, my community, and the tradition that anchored me. I could feel the weight of both worlds pressing in—Max’s hopeful eyes, the congregation’s expectation, my own longing to belong in both places. My heart pounded as I tried to figure out how to be enough for everyone, knowing that whatever I chose, something would have to give.
